docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Thursday about the economic effects of rising health insurance premiums misstated Kroger's role in a five-month supermarket labor dispute in California. The Ralph's chain, owned by Kroger, locked out union workers; they did not strike that chain, though they did strike chains operated by Safeway.
docs.abstract: Aug 19 article about economic effects of rising health insurance premiums misstated Kroger's role in five-month supermarket labor dispute in California; Ralph's chain, owned by Kroger, locked out union workers

docs.lead_paragraph: A crisis in Los Angeles County's emergency health care system became more acute this week with the announcement that the oldest hospital in the San Fernando Valley would close by Dec. 31, officials said here Friday. News of the closing of the institution, the Northridge Hospital Medical Center campus in the Van Nuys section, which opened in 1929, follows by a week the closing of the emergency room at Elastar Community Hospital in the East Los Angeles neighborhood.

headline.main: Los Angeles Emergency Care Crisis Deepens

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Employer-based health insurance is the root cause of the health care financing problem, and it can be the key to a solution.
docs.abstract: Allan Ostergren letter suggests ending tax exemption for employee health insurance and establishing universal health plan that covers catastrophic costs and sets deductibles as percent of personal income

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki wielded his veto pen on Friday to trim $235 million from the $101 billion budget that the Legislature passed last week, cutting allocations that lawmakers had added for colleges, libraries and health care. In doing so, Mr. Pataki continued a pattern set last year, in which he and the Legislature fail to agree on a budget, the Legislature puts aside its differences to pass a budget over the governor's objections, and the governor vetoes parts of the budget the Legislature passed. But while Mr. Pataki vetoed well over a billion dollars in spending last year, prompting an immediate and embarrassing override, this year's cuts were smaller, and the Republican-led Senate did not say if it would override.

headline.main: Pataki Vetoes $235 Million From Legislature's Budget

docs.abstract: Gov George Pataki vetoes $235 million in spending from $101-billion budget passed by New York Legislature (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Strategic Resource Company for about $250 million to offer benefits to uninsured workers. Aetna, based in Hartford, said it would use available cash to acquire Strategic Resource, which provides limited benefits to part-time and hourly workers. Strategic provides benefits to more than 700 employers in 46 states and Washington. Aetna expects the purchase of Strategic Resource, which is based in Columbia, S.C., to increase earnings after the deal is completed in the fourth quarter.

headline.main: AETNA TO BUY STRATEGIC RESOURCE FOR ABOUT $250 MILLION

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: American corporations are increasingly becoming noncompetitive globally because of the health care costs they must assume. Now it is reported that this burden is also responsible for the slow pace of hiring.
docs.abstract: Charles G Loeb Jr letter holds that making Medicare available to everyone would rid corporations of increasing medical premiums and ensure coverage to all citizens0

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: With an estimated 31 percent of our gross domestic product going to health care costs, both business and labor are squeezed. Workers can't afford to buy it on their own; employers increasingly cannot afford to provide it.
docs.abstract: Don C Reed letter holds that number of people with incurable diseases is real reason for increasing rise in health care costs2

docs.lead_paragraph: As one of only two functioning hospitals in Charlotte County, the Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte was deluged on Thursday with more than twice its usual number of patients. All 12 emergency room beds were taken, and patients were having their wounds cleaned in the ambulance bay by members of a federal Disaster Medical Assistance Team from the Florida Panhandle. ''If it weren't for DMAT, we would have fallen on our face,'' said Alice Carper, an emergency room charge nurse.

headline.main: Hospital Emergency Rooms Are First Line of Medical Care

docs.abstract: Emergency rooms in areas of Florida affected by Hurricane Charley are seeing large influx of patients; scene in Charlotte County, where medical assistance teams have treated more than 1,000 people, described; state has attributed 23 deaths to Charley, including 12 in aftermath; other developments noted; photo (M)

byline.original: By SHAILA K. DEWAN; Perry Athanason contributed reporting from Punta Gorda and Port Charlotte, Fla., for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: In another sign that the nation's economic recovery may be losing steam, a closely watched gauge of future business activity fell in July for a second consecutive month. The Conference Board, the business research group in New York, said yesterday that its composite index of leading economic indicators dropped 0.3 percent in July, to 116.0, after a revised decline of 0.1 percent in June -- the first time in more than a year that the index lost ground. The July decline was larger than the 0.1 percent dip forecast by analysts.

headline.main: Leading Gauge Of Economy Fell in July

docs.abstract: Conference Board's composite index of leading economic indicators drops 0.3 percent in July, to 116.0, after revised decline of 0.1 percent in June; graph; number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment insurance dips by 3,000 for week, to 331,000 (M)
